awd_titl_txt: INFEWS N/P/H2O: Development of Sustainable Nutrient Extraction and Recovery Devices (NERDs) for Municipal and Agricultural Wastewater
awd_abstract_narration:
PI Name:  Lee Blaney
Proposal Number:  1706819
 
Nutrient pollution is intricately tied to national and global issues, including water, energy, food, political, and economic security. In this project the PI will develop, optimize, and test innovative nutrient extraction and recovery devices (NERDs) to effectively recover fertilizer products rich in nitrogen and phosphorus from urban and agricultural waste streams. The recovered fertilizers will be assessed for heavy metals and contaminants of emerging concern (e.g., antibiotics, hormones, etc.) to prevent other human and ecological health concerns, such as endocrine disruption and antibiotic resistance. 

The overall goal of this research is to develop, test, and optimize a Donnan membrane principle-based process for recovery of phosphorus, nitrogen, and potassium from municipal wastewater, waste activated sludge, and agricultural waste. NERD reactors selectively concentrate and recover nutrients by exploiting electrochemical potential gradients across ion exchange membranes. The PI will systematically investigate several aspects of NERDs: (1) the capacity and rate of phosphorus, magnesium, ammonium, and potassium recovery from well-defined solutions, (2) the selective recovery of struvite and potassium struvite from synthetic wastewaters in batch and continuous flow modes to generate fertilizers with customizable nitrogen-to-phosphorus-to-potassium ratios, and (3) the application of NERD process chemistry to recover nutrients from real wastewater effluent, waste activated sludge, and animal manures and assessment of the co-recovery of traditional and emerging contaminants. The transformative nature of this project stems from the team?s completely innovative approach to nutrient recovery. The low energy, chemical, and water requirements of their process suggest that NERDs will be an attractive option for municipal wastewater treatment plants and agricultural operations in the developed and developing world; furthermore, the team believes that this novel technique can also be employed for phosphorus remediation. The significance of this work stems from the need for a new approach to capture and recycle nitrogen and phosphorus to prevent pollution of drinking water resources, protect environmental systems and aquatic habitat, and preclude loss of revenue streams from fishing, shrimping, and tourism industries.

por.por_cntn:
The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that more than 100,000 miles of rivers, 2.5 million acres of lakes, reservoirs, and ponds, and 800 square miles of bays and estuaries are negatively impacted by nutrient pollution each year. At the same time, fertilizer production involves significant energy inputs and rapid depletion of natural phosphate deposits. Development of circular nutrient economies, wherein resources are recovered from waste and converted into valuable products, can solve these interconnected issues and provide a more sustainable approach to ensuring food security and water quality in the coming decades. In this project, we developed novel Donnan dialysis-based approaches to recover nutrients from diverse waste sources.

Donnan dialysis leverages electrochemical potential gradients between waste and draw solutions that are separated by ion-exchange membranes to selectively recover target ions. Due to the unique chemistry of ion-exchange membranes, we can control the extent of target ion recovery by changing the concentration of salt in the draw solution. While the concept of Donnan dialysis was established over 100 years ago, this strategy has not been widely evaluated for nutrient recovery. The main goal of this project was to achieve greater than 90% recovery of orthophosphate (phosphorus) and ammonium (nitrogen) from waste to (i) decrease the impacts of nutrient pollution on water quality and (ii) generate sustainable, slow-release fertilizers that reduce nutrient runoff. We hypothesized that our goal of 90% nutrient recovery could be achieved for real wastes through systematic design of the draw solution, pre-treatment of the waste solution, and optimization of the membrane. The specific objectives were as follows:

  1. Conduct fundamental studies to determine the extent and rate of orthophosphate, magnesium, ammonium, and potassium recovery from synthetic wastewater using Donnan dialysis reactors equipped with flat-sheet, ion-exchange membranes;
  2. Investigate the selective recovery of struvite and potassium struvite from synthetic and real wastewaters to generate slow-release fertilizers with customizable nitrogen-to-phosphorus-to-potassium ratios; and,
  3. Demonstrate nutrient recovery from challenging wastes, including urine and metal-laden waste activated sludge, though innovative advances involving tubular anion- and cation-exchange membranes, ligand-enabled Donnan dialysis, and alternative draw solutions.

In Objective 1, we systematically investigated the impacts of the waste solution chemistry, draw solution composition, and membrane characteristics on nutrient recovery by Donnan dialysis. These efforts allowed us to calculate specific parameters that govern the uptake and transport of nutrients in ion-exchange membranes. We also defined a new parameter, Rd/w, which is the ratio of total ion concentration in the draw solution to that in the waste solution, to serve as the master design variable for Donnan dialysis systems. Using an Rd/w of 10, we were able to consistently achieve at least 90% recovery for orthophosphate, magnesium, ammonium, and potassium. In Objective 2, we modified the nutrient-enriched draw solutions with magnesium chloride and sodium hydroxide to precipitate nutrient-laden particles. Chemical analysis, chemical equilibrium modeling, and solids characterization were employed to confirm that the recovered particles were mostly struvite minerals, which are sustainable, slow-release fertilizers. In Objective 3, we made several innovative advances to conventional Donnan dialysis. First, we developed a novel reactor with tubular ion-exchange membranes to enable simultaneous recovery of anionic and cationic nutrients by Donnan dialysis. Second, we demonstrated ligand-enabled Donnan dialysis for nutrient recovery from challenging solid wastes, such as alum-laden waste activated sludge. Third, we highlighted the ability of reverse osmosis concentrate, another waste stream, to be successfully deployed as an alternative draw solution in Donnan dialysis, thereby decreasing the operating costs of nutrient recovery applications and enabling co-treatment of two wastes. Overall, the intellectual merit generated by this project informed the fundamental design and operation of both conventional and advanced Donnan dialysis systems to recover nutrients from diverse wastes.

The broader impacts of this project were mainly focused on the education, training, and professional development of students. One postdoctoral research associate, two PhD students, one MS student, and six BS students completed the experimental work needed to address the aforementioned specific objectives. Three students were African American, one student was Hispanic American, five students were women, and one student had a disability. All students presented their work at regional, national, or international conferences. Based on their research training and outcomes, the students are well prepared to enter academia or the workforce to continue advancing the new technologies needed to enable circular nutrient economies. We also conducted outreach to campus organizations, including the Center for Women in Technology, the Meyerhoff Scholars Program, and the Honors College, to not only describe the project motivation and results, but also to inspire, encourage, and guide students to undergraduate research opportunities. Ultimately, this project provided the following benefits to society: reduced nutrient pollution of water resources; sustainable fertilizers for food security; innovative technologies for managing nutrient cycles; and, workforce development through student training and research.
